items.title: Canadian ski jumper Abi Strate captures 1st career World Cup gold
items.summary_auto: Canadian ski jumper Abi Strate started the new year with a bang by soaring to her first career World Cup victory on Thursday.

items.title: It’s a new year — and these Europeans are diving in
items.summary_auto: It’s a new year, and for some in Europe, that means it’s time for a chilly plunge to get 2026 started.

items.title: No drop in Calgarians' water usage despite request from city after water main break
items.summary_auto: A day after officials first asked Calgarians to reduce their water use in the wake of Tuesday’s catastrophic water main break, the city says it is not seeing any real reduction in usage.

items.title: New safe supply rules take effect in B.C., with mixed reactions
items.summary_auto: Most people who take prescription opioids as an alternative to illicit drugs must now take them under the supervision of a pharmacist. Some worry the move will push people back to toxic street drugs, while others say the changes were long overdue.

items.title: Why this former Hab auctioned off his Stanley Cup ring — and how much it sold for
items.summary_auto: Longtime NHL defenceman Petr Svoboda recently auctioned off his Stanley Cup ring from the Montreal Canadiens’ 1986 championship to raise funds for a cause that hits close to home.

items.title: Man arrested after woman allegedly pushed from 3-storey balcony in Montreal
items.summary_auto: A 31-year-old man has been arrested after a woman was allegedly pushed from a balcony in Montreal early Thursday, police say. The woman, also 31, was found unconscious on the ground and taken to hospital in critical condition.

items.title: Around 40 dead, more than 100 injured in blaze at Swiss ski resort bar during New Year's Eve party
Mamdani vows to govern 'expansively and audaciously' in inaugural speech as NYC mayor
items.summary_auto: Zohran Mamdani was sworn in as the mayor of New York City just after midnight Thursday, taking the oath of office at a historic, decommissioned subway station in Manhattan.

items.title: Trump's 'unprecedented' diplomat recall sparks concerns over politicization of foreign service
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration’s recent recall of 30 career diplomats from around the world as part of its "America First" priority push is unprecedented, according to experts who say it may serve to politicize the American Foreign Service while populating it with those who lack the skills to deal with challenging diplomatic issues.

items.title: After terminal diagnosis, this Hamiltonian is focusing on love, bucket lists and living fully in 2026
items.summary_auto: Cole DeLargie-Campbell is a 38-year-old living in Hamilton. They were diagnosed with a rare, grade three meningioma and given six to 12 months to live.

items.title: Canada's grocery code of conduct kicks in today, with buy-in from 5 major grocers
items.summary_auto: The voluntary grocery code of conduct for grocers, suppliers, wholesalers and primary producers in Canada is set to fully roll out on Thursday.

items.title: Father and son dress as Santa, visit Gaza tent city with gifts, music to celebrate New Year
items.summary_auto: Sunset bathed the north of Gaza City in golden light Tuesday evening as Izzat Al-Qawasmeh and his 11-year-old son Mohamed climbed through rubble to the top of a building that once housed hundreds of people. The duo had decided to visit the tent city with gifts, dressed in Santa Claus costumes.

items.title: Cool space stuff you don’t want to miss in 2026, including a Canadian who’s heading to the moon
items.summary_auto: This year brought us our third-known interstellar visitor, beautiful displays of the northern lights and the opening of the Vera C. Rubin Observatory that will change our views on the universe in ways we have yet to understand. But now, we look ahead to just some of the cool things skywatchers might want to keep an eye on in 2026.

items.title: A small shop in Saguenay, Que., sewed up the contract to dress Canada’s highest court
items.summary_auto: How to balance tradition with modernization? The team at Les Rabat-Joies in Saguenay, Que., got the opportunity to spruce up the wardrobe for Canada’s nine justices of the Supreme Court.

items.title: New year, new tax measures: What to expect in 2026
items.summary_auto: The coming year will see some changes to existing tax measures, the abandonment of others and some help for personal support workers. But overall changes to the taxes individuals pay will be minor in 2026.

items.title: Some snowbirds want out of Florida. A bad housing market makes it hard to leave
items.summary_auto: As the era of bilateral bad blood between Canada and the U.S. drags on, some snowbirds are facing a choice this January: Go south to warmer climes, or boycott a country that has gone from friend to somewhat of a foe.
